reviews.review: This is the best video game I've ever played. Gamers who love medieval history and storytelling - this is it. I've played countless games over years and I remember every single one vividly. Perfect blend of character-driven roleplaying and grand strategy. THE game.

Having loved Crusader Kings II, I went into CK3 with high hopes. After spending a good amount of time with the game, I can say that while I like Crusader Kings III, I’ll never feel as excited about it as I was with its predecessor. The leap from CK2 to CK3 feels minor in terms of gameplay evolution — outside of the graphical improvements, the core mechanics haven’t been significantly expanded upon.

Unfortunately, the major issue that plagued CK2, namely repetitiveness, hasn't been adequately addressed. There are moments of brilliance, and it's still a fun game for those who enjoy grand strategy, but it lacks the depth and novelty to keep me as engaged as CK2 did over the years.

If you’re new to the series, CK3 is a solid place to start. But for veterans of CK2, the experience may feel more familiar than fresh.

This is one of the most complex and immersive Medieval sim games. BUT a word of caution for new players. DO NOT buy this game if you are interested in in-depth medieval war strategy. War in this game is genuinely awful. Considering war makes up a large chunk of this game and medieval history it is by far the most boring and one-dimensional part of the game and can often be bugged out or have wars randomly invalidated. 

What this game is is more of a political simulator and via strategic marriages, alliances, schemes and factions.

The other thing with this game has is that almost everything relies on some form of chance (apart from war which is dull and flaccid). You don't play the game so much as it plays you by hurling events and situations your way with limited ways on how to play.

One of the best things about this game is the stress mechanic, which punishes play outside of your characters personality e.g. a compassionate person randomly insulting a vassal at a feast will give stress. It adds a great dynamic for role-playing. A bit like life, this game is very hard to control the outcomes and about 90% of the game (If you are playing a Duke or greater title) is crisis management.

To sum up
Positives:
Great role-playing
Intrigue is interesting and versatile
True political sim
True dynasty building
Interesting historical events and regions

Negatives:
War is dull considering how much of it is in the game
DLCs are expensive and sometimes not worth the money (read reviews to see which are the best)
RN-Jesus can bring a play-through catapulting to a halt via a series of unfortunate events

I would recommend this game.

Every time I come back to CK3 I am disappointed by how little the game has improved since the last time I played. The game still doesn't have any real difficulty to it, getting OP alliances is still trivial, and you don't even need them 90% of the time. It still feels like a slog to the inevitable.

The only things they're adding are random notifications and events that even if I read, I do not find interesting anymore. Or mechanics that unnecessarily bloat the game without adding depth, like the most recent legitimacy or plague mechanics. Legitimacy is a nice concept but I never felt in my last 2 runs that its execution made any sense or had any real impact. Overall, compared to at release, to me CK3 now feels like just a more bloated, obnoxious version of the same game.

I always liked the statecraft in the game, developing holdings, culture, religion and a dynasty over time. I feel like updates and DLCs haven't focused on that at all, to the game's detriment. I suppose it took me 170 hours too long to figure out that this game just isn't for me, as I imagine many people probably like these sorts of things about the game.

TL;DR: I think the game gets worse over time, just like Stellaris. Lots of wasted potential.

I have played the tutorial for this game 5 times and still don’t understand how to survive an hour past the guardrails coming off. DLC pricing compared to features added is absolutely insane and leaves a lot to be desired. I do feel like the total war series is a bit more captivating for this type of gameplay, but this has its own loyal fan base. 

It feels a bit underwhelming to be told so plainly, what is happening—instead of actually experiencing it. It never really managed to hook me—yet here I go, for round 6

whelp i've dropped too many hours into this to not give some kind of review. it's a dope game on the whole, and well worth picking up if you're the type to partake in content like The Rest Is History, Epic HIstory TV, and have a youtube algorithm of an 80 year old retiree, this is the game for you. 

it's not without faults. basically any crusades feel very bleh, but with more DLC comes more character. Some DLC is defo not a requirement. I could go on, but it's more about rough edges you start noticing after a hundred hours or so. 

The roadmap has stayed true, and the quality of DLC is getting better each season. So if you end up liking vanilla, there are quite a few options on what you're looking to tickle your pickle.

Can't play with new update. I started the tutorial yesterday to try to learn the game. After an update today, the game constantly and consistently crashes about 5 minutes into the tutorial. I have spent more time trying to figure out how to get the game to not crash than actually playing it.

CK3 is a fun game, but Paradox just insists on screwing over "base game" players. The latest offence is the "Court Grandeur " system they decided to foist into the base game. Essentially, it's a system introduced in the Royal Court DLC that makes a court and throne room available for you to manage. (You hang pelts from hunts and other trophies in your throne room etc.) But you can't even see what the score of your court is unless you buy the DLC. Now your vassals are mad because your court is lame and you don't even know what the score of your court is or how to manage it. Totally unmanageable in the base game but you're subject to it. They've done it before with the "legitimacy" mechanic in a previous patch. Just makes me not want to play this any more, since they keep doing things to screw up games I've already got in progress. So, yeah, play it if you don't mind opening the wallet for all the pricey DLC they want you to buy.

Worst sequel ive ever seen, literally took all the joy and fun out of ck2 and stripped all the dlc from ck2 just so that they could re-release it one at a time over the course of the next 25 years with random "Culture packs" sprinkled throughout for $25 a pop. Easily a scam.
The new update completely broke my game. Can't get through two minutes of gameplay without it crashing

Crusader Kings is my favorite game series of all time but it is the only game I don't actively push on to anyone. If this is your cup of tea, it might as wall be a cup of liquid cocaine. If you are a fan of Historical Fiction, Medieval Fantasy Role Playing, or Intense Grand Strategy games, this is for you. 

The new Road to Power DLC is probably one of the most refreshing gameplay changes to the series I have played. Adventuring leads to so much fun roleplaying and gameplay. From leaving Italy as a the 3rd son of a count to moving to the Byzantine's, blackmailing the Basileus and fighting in his holy wars, seducing the guest of honor at his chariot race and then running away from my lover and her 3 new bastard sons to install my daughter as the Queen of Poland after winning the crusades for her. 

10/10

Crusader Kings 3 is an excellent game—I currently own about half of the DLC released in the first year or so, including Northern Lords, Royal Court, Iberia, Wards and Wardens, and more. I hadn’t played in over a year and thought I'd dive back in.

However, catching up on the expansions would now cost me around £60, even with a sale. That’s essentially the price of a full AAA game just to get back up to date, which feels borderline obscene. I get that continuous development requires funding through DLC, and that’s understandable. But then I remember I paid £15 for Starsector, and its indie dev team has been providing substantial updates for over a decade.

But hey, gotta keep the shareholders happy, right?

This pricing model has drained any motivation I have to return to CK3. As much as I love the game, I'll be exploring other titles for now.

I LOVE PAINTING THE MAP, fun but gets old fairly fast, tech upgrades take FOREVER. ez 100 hours of playtime. Worth it if its your first map painter but if you have other paradox titles this isnt worth the money, 8/10 tho.

I thought I would really enjoy this game, unfortunately that wasn't the case. The quick tutorial didn't really explain making money that well, so when my king died, it all went downhill very quickly. Why can't you wage war when you're in debt? The troop movement felt terrible and battles were boring. I ended up playing too long to get a refund, I am quite disappointed about this fact. I'll give it the fact it was quite engaging and there are some positives about the game for sure, for me however, it was far outweighed by the negatives.

Was amazing when i first bought this game. Sank so many hours into it and it had me hooked from the start, but now it is unplayable. Every time I try starting the game it crashes with no explanation despite having run perfectly before and for the life of me I cant find a reason why or how to fix it
The game is nice, but the amount of DLCs is outrageous. Most of those things should be on the main game. Not worth the steep price.

They just pushed a patch that broke the game. aaaand they lock basic features and updates behind hundreds of dollars of DLC. Your money will be better spent on something else. Wish I could tell this to my past self.

I played over 1k hours and plan to play many more, so why a negative review? Because cool as it is this game needs heavy reworking.

There are so many cool features one can simply ignore and the difficulty level is really trivial, and the scaling and balance of various aspects of the game are terrible.

And let's not forget crusades... they are a mess.

Once these things will be fixed I'll change my reviev into positive.

The game is too easy - retinues are absurdly powerful and with good play you snowball so fast that the game stops being challenging really fast. I like the stress system a lot, but other than that, the game failed to keep my attention for long.

It's honestly just inferior CK2 after 4 years. Only three good things are it looks better graphically, integrates -parts- of CK2 DLC into the base game and runs better later into the game. Two of those things come from using a more modern version of their engine and instituting character culling measures that were added late into CK2. There are still major parts of the previous game missing in this game (playable Republics, trade, culturals, bloodlines, societies and others) and there are still a ton of flavorless regions.

Yeah I get it Crusader Kings however, they clearly don't care about that as Crusades are still incredibly dumb, the AI clearly just doesn't know how to coordinate especially with the supply system. Tens of thousands of starving crusaders constantly getting wiped out because the game doesn't let you stockpile for crossing an ocean then fighting a prolonged campaign.
